timeline.message:
Defined OperationPriority.
Created PriorityBlockingDrainingQueue (+tests).
Integrated with CompletableOperation (+tests)
Integrated with OperationProcessor (no tests yet).
Integrated with DurableLog (no tests yet).

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

Throttler: added a way to temporarily suspend throttling.
OperationProcessor: wired up Throttler suspension (+ unit tests).

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

Throttler: not going in a loop if max==true and suspended.

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

DeleteSegmentOperations have OperationPriority.Critical.

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

Attributes.ATTRIBUTE_SEGMENT_TYPE is used to store SegmentMetadata.getType. This is refreshed every time the SegmentMetadata is activated (loaded from a checkpoint) or from the MetadataStore (via StreamSegmentMapOperation).
This attribute is immutable once the segment is created. Some of its values may be inferred from existing attributes.

StreamSegmentStore: Updated createStreamSegment to accept a SegmentType.
TableStore: Updated createdSegment to accept SegmentType instead of "boolean sorted".

PravegaRequestProcessor, TableBasedMetadataStore, TableMetadataStore: setting correct SegmentTypes on all created segments.

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

All Segment Store Operations have OperationType. Deletion is the most exciting one.
Added OperationPriority.High - reserved for non-critical system segments.
Added PriorityCalculator that helps figure out operation priorities. Wired up in StreamSegmentContainer.

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

Retired OperationLog.add (without priority).

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

Updated unit tests for StreamSegmentContainer.

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

Merge remote-tracking branch 'origin/master' into issue-5260-qos

# Conflicts:
#	segmentstore/server/src/test/java/io/pravega/segmentstore/server/tables/ContainerTableExtensionImplTests.java

timeline.bodyText: Should we add back the createSegment(String segmentName, Duration timeout)  overload that creates normal segments?
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi
timeline.diffHunk:
@@ -65,38 +66,23 @@ */ int MAXIMUM_VALUE_LENGTH = 1024 * 1024 - MAXIMUM_KEY_LENGTH; - /** - * Creates a new Segment and marks it as a Table Segment. This will be a non-sorted Table Segment. - * See {@link #createSegment(String, boolean, Duration)} (invoked with sorted:=false). - * This segment may not be used for Streaming purposes (i.e., it cannot be used with {@link StreamSegmentStore}). - * - * @param segmentName The name of the Table Segment to create. - * @param timeout Timeout for the operation. - * @return A CompletableFuture that, when completed normally, will indicate the operation completed. If the operation - * failed, the future will be failed with the causing exception. Notable Exceptions: - *
    - *
  • {@link StreamSegmentExistsException} If the Segment does exist (whether as a Table Segment or Stream Segment). - *
- */ - default CompletableFuture createSegment(String segmentName, Duration timeout) { - return createSegment(segmentName, false, timeout); - } - /** * Creates a new Segment and marks it as a Table Segment. * This segment may not be used for Streaming purposes (i.e., it cannot be used with {@link StreamSegmentStore}). * * @param segmentName The name of the Table Segment to create. - * @param sorted EXPERIMENTAL. If true, the created Table Segment will be a Sorted Table Segment, otherwise it - * will be a plain Hash Table. See {@link TableStore} Javadoc for difference between the two. + * @param segmentType Type of Segment to Create. If not already specified, this will automatically set the + * {@link SegmentType#isTableSegment()} to true. If {@link SegmentType#isSortedTableSegment()} + * is true, this will create a Sorted Table Segment (EXPERIMENTAL), otherwise it will be a plain + * Hash Table. See {@link TableStore} Javadoc for difference between the two. * @param timeout Timeout for the operation. * @return A CompletableFuture that, when completed normally, will indicate the operation completed. If the operation * failed, the future will be failed with the causing exception. Notable Exceptions: *
    *
  • {@link StreamSegmentExistsException} If the Segment does exist (whether as a Table Segment or Stream Segment). *
*/ - CompletableFuture createSegment(String segmentName, boolean sorted, Duration timeout); + CompletableFuture createSegment(String segmentName, SegmentType segmentType, Duration timeout);

replies.bodyText:
I thought about it. It would save some unit test churn. But the reason we had 2 overloads in the first place was because I was lazy to begin with and didn't want to update all unit tests.
IMO, having 2 overloads is asking for even more overloads to be added in the future as we change things. SegmentType should encompass any type of segment that we would envision creating so I really did not want to have a "default" overload. Plus, what is "normal" anyway?
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.bodyText:
why not ROLE_CRITICAL = 0b0100_0000L | ROLE_INTERNAL also?
What is the difference between internal and system ?
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText:
The point of Internal is to differentiate between Segment Store-owned segments and external ones. In the future we may restrict access to such segments externally. All system segments are internal, but not all internal segments may require the "elevated" priority that system segments have.
Critical segments need not necessarily be internal segments. The Controller may designate some segments (i.e., Event stream or whatever) as critical to the good functioning of the cluster. At this point we didn't label any of these as such, nor do we expose segment type via the Wire Protocol. But it is something that may be done in the future.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

replies.bodyText: ok. So internal means only Segment Store-owned segments not "pravega internal"
replies.author: sachin-j-joshi

timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

timeline.bodyText: Can we add these as static constants to SegmentType itself?
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

timeline.bodyText: I am not sure I understood what is happening here. In earlier line we overwrote this.type from attributes, then why would this if condition ever be true?
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText: Backwards compatibility. The Segment type does not exist prior to version 0.9 and segments may have already been created in upgraded clusters. We can still infer the format of the type (Stream/Table/SortedTable) by looking at existing attributes.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

There is no state here.

timeline.bodyText: PriorityCalculator.getPriority could be static. We could avoid some allocations here.
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

timeline.bodyText: Will this really cover al valid combinations?
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText: There are too many combinations to test. I created a few important ones a few lines above (Stream segment, system stream segment, sorted table segment and critical internal) which should cover all the bits that can be set. The point of this test is not to exhaustively test all possibilities (SegmentTypeTests does that), but to verify that this is properly stored in the metadata store when creating segments.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.bodyText:
why can't updateAttributes itself do what refresh is doing?
I think it will make it less error prone.
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText:
I want this externally accessible so I can unit test it properly.
Also, there are cases where updateAttributes is invoked where we need not invoke this one as well. One case involves deserialization of metadata, while another is the fact that once created, the segment type should never be changed, hence not invoking this everywhere.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.message:
Code review feedback.

Signed-off-by: Andrei Paduroiu <andrei.paduroiu@emc.com>

timeline.bodyText:
Can new item with higher priority be inserted between getFirstIndex and getQueue?
More importantly does it matter in this case that we skipped over higher priority item in this case? If not then at least add a comment that explains the behavior.
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText: No. Because while invoking this method, we are holding the lock (from the super class). See this method's Javadoc in the superclass.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.bodyText:
If all queues are empty then we'll return -1 .
This will result in index out of bound
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText: If all the queues are empty then the if(this.size == 0) above will fire and return an empty ArrayDequeue. So we shouldn't even get here anyway.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu

timeline.bodyText: what happens when all queues are empty?
timeline.author: sachin-j-joshi

replies.bodyText:
Returns -1. But see my comment above about how this is used.
The unit tests cover this case.
replies.author: andreipaduroiu
